DOC.brief_summary: The purpose study test feasibility effectiveness vitamin K injection certain body part treatment painful menstruation .
DOC.brief_title: Vitamin K Injections Treatment Painful Menstruation
DOC.detailed_description: Painful menstruation , also know dysmenorrhea , common problem affect significant percentage woman . In United States Europe , nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug ( NSAIDs ) oral contraceptive commonly prescribe treatment condition . However , China , oral contraceptive commonly prescribe unmarried woman . Acu-injection , procedure involve injection vitamin K acupuncture point , become standard treatment dysmenorrhea many Chinese health care facility . This trial ass willingness young Chinese woman participate acu-injection trial , explore utility pain measurement injection , determine effectiveness injection . This study also help plan large acu-injection clinical trial . This study last five menstrual cycle . Participants randomly assign one three group . Group 1 participant receive vitamin K3 injection acupuncture point leg saline injection right buttock . Group 2 participant receive saline injection acupuncture point leg saline injection right buttock . Group 3 participant receive saline injection pseudo-acupuncture point leg vitamin K3 injection right buttock . Injections administer one time first 2 day first menstrual cycle participant experience menstrual pain . Participants record level menstrual pain injection 2 , 5 , 30 60 minute injection . Participants respond satisfied acu-injection treatment offer either Chinese herbal medicine NSAIDs within 1 hour injection . After injection visit , participant ask complete questionnaire menstrual pain side effect may experience five subsequent menstrual cycle .
DOC.criteria: Dysmenorrhea least 6 month prior study entry Have never pregnant give birth Mandarin Chinese Shanghainese speak Regular menstrual cycle least 6 month prior diagnosis dysmenorrhea Has working home phone cellular phone Willing disclose address Intends stay area study Parent guardian willing provide inform consent , applicable Dysmenorrhea due suspect recognized cause Current use hormonal contraceptive intrauterine device History abdominal surgery Other concomitant therapy acute chronic pain Anticoagulant drug Vitamin K acuinjections leg acupuncture point prior study entry Intolerance NSAIDs Known allergy vitamin K
